channel.title: NYT > Obituaries
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Robert Duvall, ‘Godfather’ and ‘Apocalypse Now’ Actor, Dies at 95
item.description: An Oscar winner, he was known for disappearing into wide-ranging roles in movies like “Apocalypse Now” and “The Godfather” and in the television series “Lonesome Dove.”
item.dc:creator: Clyde Haberman
item.media:description: In a long and varied career, Robert Duvall was nominated for seven Academy Awards for acting, and won once.

item.title: Frederick Wiseman, 96, Penetrating Documentarian of Institutions, Dies
item.description: He exposed abuses in films like “Titicut Follies,” a once-banned portrait of a mental hospital, but ranged widely in subject matter, from a Queens neighborhood to a French restaurant.
item.dc:creator: John Anderson
item.media:description: Mr. Wiseman in an undated photo. “I don’t know if I can offer a general definition of what I’m doing,” he said in 2011, “except to say I’m trying to create dramatic structures out of ordinary experience.”

item.title: Richard Ottinger, 97, Dies; Fought for the Environment in Congress
item.description: A New York Democrat, he spent 16 years in the House over two stretches, beginning in 1965, championing the health of the Hudson River and opposing the Vietnam War.
item.dc:creator: Joseph P. Fried and Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Richard Ottinger in 1970. He served six years in the House of Representatives beginning in 1965 and another 10 years starting in 1975.

item.title: Dana Eden, Co-Creator of ‘Tehran,’ Dies During Filming of Fourth Season
item.description: Ms. Eden, 52, who was also an executive producer of the Emmy-winning show, was found in a hotel room in Athens. Greek police said they did not suspect foul play.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Dana Eden at the premier of Season 2 of “Tehran” in New York in 2022.

item.title: Jerry Kennedy, Who Helped Define Music in Nashville, Dies at 85
item.description: A guitarist and record producer, he played a role in creating hits by popular singers like Roger Miller, Roy Orbison, Tom T. Hall and Tammy Wynette.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.category: Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum
item.media:description: Jerry Kennedy in the 1970s posing at the Mercury Records studio control board in Nashville. “Jerry is truly one of the lead architects in the creation of the Nashville sound,” said Marty Stuart, a member of the Country Music Hall of Fame.

item.title: Henrike Naumann, Artist Set to Represent Germany at Venice Biennale, Dies at 41
item.description: Her death from cancer was the second sudden loss for this year’s edition. Naumann’s exhibition will still go ahead in May, according to a statement.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Henrike Naumann, who was born in East Germany, became known for installations featuring household items that reflect historical and political events.

item.title: Alfred Blumstein, Who Transformed the Study of Crime, Dies at 95
item.description: An engineer by training, he used systems theory and quantitative analysis to examine criminal behavior, revealing the systemic patterns of crime.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: How The Times Remembered 15 Winter Olympics Greats
item.description: Obituaries have memorialized the lives of a figure-skating trailblazer, a “Miracle on Ice” hockey player, a bobsledder who overcame blindness, and more.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Woolfe and Amisha Padnani
item.media:description: Rosi Mittermaier of Germany competing in 1969. She went on win two women’s Alpine skiing events in the 1976 Olympics and narrowly missed winning a third.

item.title: ElRoy Face, Ace Forkballer and Effective Closer for Pirates, Dies at 97
item.description: Face was one of the first major-league hurlers to make the closer job a specialty. Not an overpowering pitcher, he finagled outs with a tricky forkball.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.media:description: ElRoy Face followed through after serving up a pitch against the Yankees at Yankee Stadium in the fifth game of the 1960 World Series. Face helped take the Pirates to a stunning defeat of the Yankees that year.

item.title: King Leatherbury, Trainer and Trader of Horses, Dies at 92
item.description: He trained mostly lesser-known, cheaper thoroughbreds in Maryland and was the fifth-winningest trainer in North American history.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: King Leatherbury at Laurel Park racetrack in Maryland in 2003. He was inducted into the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in 2015.

item.title: Roy Medvedev, Soviet Era Historian and Dissident, Is Dead at 100
item.description: His score of books and hundreds of essays documented Stalinist executions, Communist repressions and censorship, and the transition to post-Soviet Russia.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Roy Medvedev in Moscow in 1990. In the West, he was known as the most independent historian of the Soviet era.

item.title: David J. Farber, ‘Grandfather of the Internet,’ Dies at 91
item.description: A researcher, professor and federal policy adviser, he guided students who went on to do groundbreaking work in connecting the world online.
item.dc:creator: Peter Wayner

item.title: Ebo Taylor, Musical Innovator of Highlife and Afrobeat, Dies at 90
item.description: Borrowing from jazz and African rhythms, he forged a singular style that helped define music in his native Ghana — and West Africa — for a generation.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Ebo Taylor performing in 2011 in Wiltshire, England. In his final years, he began to receive international recognition.

item.title: Bob Croft, Who Dived Deep Into the Ocean on a Single Breath, Dies at 91
item.description: His derring-do and unusual lung capacity led him to make record-breaking dives of more than 200 feet into the Atlantic without wearing a scuba tank or fins.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Vicki Abt, Who Said TV Talk Shows Coarsened Society, Dies at 83
item.description: A Penn State sociology professor, she warned that hosts like Oprah Winfrey exploited vulnerable guests on television and sensationalized deviancy.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Greg Brown, Guitarist Who Wrote Cake’s Biggest Hit, Dies at 56
item.description: His song “The Distance,” released in 1996, became an anthem for the disaffected members of Generation X.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Mr. Brown in 1996. He left Cake after “Fashion Nugget,” partly over differences with the lead singer, John McCrea.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Clifford Brown, Trumpeter Whose Brief Life Left a Lasting Mark
item.description: He was one of the most talked-about jazz musicians in the 1950s. After he died in a car accident at 25, his influence grew.
item.dc:creator: Peter Keepnews

item.title: Daniel Cathiard Dies at 81; Turned Bordeaux Estate Into Champion Winery
item.description: He came to winemaking late, after a career in retail, and turned the 18th-century Chateau Smith Haut Lafitte into one of France’s most esteemed vineyards.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: Chateau Smith Haut Lafitte (Pessac-Leognan, France, Winery)
item.media:description: Daniel Cathiard in 2025. When he and his wife, Florence, bought Chateau Smith Haut Lafitte in 1990, wine critics thought its best days were behind it.

item.title: Helmuth Rilling, Who Recorded Huge Swaths of Bach, Dies at 92
item.description: He was the first to record all of J.S. Bach’s nearly 200 sacred cantatas, a project that stood out not only for its range but also for its steadfast style.
item.dc:creator: David Allen
item.media:description: Helmuth Rilling conducting Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion” at Carnegie Hall in 2007. His cycle of that composer’s nearly 200 surviving sacred cantatas engaged him from 1969 to 1985.

item.title: Bud Cort, Who Starred in 1971’s ‘Harold and Maude,’ Dies at 77
item.description: The role, one of his first, made him a household name and a film idol of the anti-establishment 1970s. But it also limited his growth as an actor.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Bud Cort as the teenager Harold Chasen who falls in love with a 79-year-old woman in Hal Ashby’s movie “Harold and Maude,” from 1971. Panned at first, it became a cult classic.

item.title: Tamas Vasary, Pianist of Power and Sensitivity, Dies at 92
item.description: He bought technical brilliance and stylistic authority to Romantic-era music, particularly the works of Chopin and Liszt.
item.dc:creator: Tim Page
item.media:credit: Erich Auerbach/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Tamas Vasary around 1965. He was best known for his many recordings, most of them on the Deutsche Grammophon label.

item.title: Ken Peplowski, Who Helped Revive the Jazz Clarinet, Dies at 66
item.description: Also a saxophone standout, he served as stylistic bridge between the Benny Goodman swing era and the genre-blurring present.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ken Peplowski in 2010 with the guitarist James Chirillo at the Lucille Lortel Theater in Manhattan. The musician and critic Russell Davies once called Mr. Peplowski “arguably the greatest living jazz clarinetist.”

item.title: LaMonte McLemore, Founding Singer With the 5th Dimension, Dies at 90
item.description: His group notched smooth hippie-era hits like “Up, Up and Away” and “The Age of Aquarius” in embracing a genre-blurring sound they called “champagne soul.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: LaMonte McLemore, second from left, performing with the 5th Dimension on television in 1970. With him, from left, were Florence LaRue, Ron Townson, Billy Davis Jr. and Marilyn McCoo. From 1967 to 1973, the group notched 20 Top 40 singles.

item.title: Andrew Ranken, Whose Drumming Powered the Pogues, Dies at 72
item.description: Known as “The Clobberer,” he pounded out driving rhythms that fueled the band’s boisterous blend of traditional Irish music, rock and punk.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Andrew Ranken performing with the Pogues in Manchester, England, in 2013.

item.title: James Van Der Beek, ‘Dawson’s Creek’ Actor, Dies at 48 After Cancer Battle
item.description: He first appeared in a hit TV drama as a wide-eyed 15-year-old who then grew up over six seasons. He announced he had cancer in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates
item.media:description: James Van Der Beek in 2002. His character in “Dawson’s Creek” knew, as he put it, the “unyielding, merciless torture” of unrequited love.

item.title: Ray Mouton Dies at 78; Lawyer Warned of Pedophilia in the Catholic Church
item.description: After defending one of the first priests charged with child sex abuse, he coauthored a 1985 report warning that the problem was endemic and ignoring it could be catastrophic.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Hudson Talbott Dies at 76; Wrote and Illustrated Wide-Ranging Children’s Books
item.description: His book about time-traveling dinosaurs became a Steven Spielberg-produced movie, and he adapted the Stephen Sondheim musical “Into the Woods” for young readers.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Gabor Boritt, Refugee Who Became Expert on Lincoln, Dies at 86
item.description: He survived the Holocaust and Communist rule in Hungary, arrived penniless in New York and made himself into a pre-eminent Civil War scholar.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History
item.media:description: Gabor Boritt in 2006. At Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania, near the site of the 1863 battle that changed the course of the Civil War, he built a career around Abraham Lincoln.

item.title: Philippe Gaulier, Clown Who Taught Actors Like Sacha Baron Cohen, Dies at 82
item.description: He often insulted his pupils, but many became stars, including Sacha Baron Cohen, Emma Thompson and Rachel Weisz.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
